Tr NApoII, July IA, 1891.


To I'm. l.. Stone, Esq. editor ofMe N I, &. .4do.


Sir: You lament the want of direct ana correct
information upon the condition and wants o Greece,
and you have reason to do so, nor you alone, but


poor Greece has reason bitterly to lament that her
situation is not known in America for had it been
Americans, by applying the means which they have
sent here in different manner, might have been
the means Of saving her from destruction. Greece,
my dear sir, is in deplorabe state-it is useless to
conceal truth her enemies without ignorant
and weak, but her enemies within are strong and
terrible; the Turk brings trouble and distress upon
the country. but the Greek brings teniod misery,
wOe and ruin. The accursed intrigues and Jealousy,
the avarice and lust of power of her civil and militia.


ry arstocracy have brought the country to the brink
of ruin. from which miracle only save her, and
that miracle would be the repentance and better
conduct of these men. Look, sir, at he state OF
the Peloponessus there YOU see the flag of liberty
waving upon the walls Of three proud fortresses !;
but these iorresses are the of intrigue. OF
plotting of secret. nay, Of open internal war. The
other night, while the army of the Pacha was with
in eight hours march of this place, was aroused
by the roar of cannon, and the rattlng of musket-
ry; arme myselfin the thought that the Turks
had made sudden assault upon the place. aud
was astonohed to find no movement on the part OF


the inhabitants-each remained still i'll his house,
. as though aware of what was going on ; and soon
= learned that Colocor0n, with a band OF soldiers,
had assaulted the castle, in hopes to master IT,
, and make himself independent, both by It's pos


session and that of the treasures Of DllyaDs, which


he knew were concealed here This is the man
= whom see YOU hold high in esteem in America, fol
his courage and patriotism =! Match me, ye Gods


match me another man who has drawn upon TN


Peloponessus so many mlserles Coocoruni.


They talk of Ibrahim Pacha he has ruined and


driven from their homes thousands Of ptaaantrv--
: Coocotron has ground them to the dust. and wrun!
e from them their little gain BY his enormous eSac
r tons the Pacha. has defeated the soltiery---Coo


coron has paralyzed them: the Pacha has opcnl
: assaulted and taken towns from his enem'es-Coo


cotroni has worked to gain hy intrigue; and assault


ed at midnight castles and towns held By men ACTIN
under the orders of government the Pacha has dis
- trcssed the government by hts movements aud depre
dations--Coortroni has still more distressed it b.
N his demands for pay and rations for armies whlc
he never raised by his intrigue by his secret opposi
- ton and open war. Leave aside his proceedings II
n 1924, his nrigues and open opposition aud rebellion
against the lawful governmenths defeat and lmpr's
s. onmen lsAas look at him since his leaving his con
,c hnement Svhe monastery at Hydra, and his berom
a. ling ceneral-in chief of TIL Morea how often an


loudly has he talked Of the death and destru ction
was preparing for the Turks how often has denan


ded and received large supplies from government


and from his province, which he has either sold OF
H. given to his creatures it is true, he has sailed on

against the enemy-he has examined them with his
spy-glass from some mountain side but never, no,
not in one single instance, has he or his Immediate
followers ventured their precious persons within the
range of shot He is bold and daring. but not before
an armed enemy; it is in int rigue and plotting to
get himself and friends in power it is in pundering
and anassing treasures for his own Golfers Where
are the of TlppoIizza, and Napo'l, which
he took as Commander inchietfr the Government!
Where his bankers in Zane, and different parts OF
Italy, where he has large sums. while he makes the
poor peasantry pay for the articles Of his own
table. How he got his former reputation for courage
know not but now his name here is getting to be
a mockery. and he is known only as a man who will
sacrifice the public for party good. who would sell
his country, nay, his soul, his God, for gold. My
language may seem to you strong and impasslonet,
but ii is the language OF man, who engaged with
all hsheart in the best cause Tor which people ever
vet drew the sword, sees that cause endangered by
the sefshness of those most bound TO support 1t !;
of one, who sees his adopted country about to be
sacrificed on the altar olavarlce and selfish ambition;
of one. who ignorant but naturally anteUagea
and virtuous people neglected nay betrayed by their
leaders. speak to YOU Of Coloctroni-not because
he alone ia the Of iniquity, not because he
ia the worst--hut, because his name sknown TO you


am not of his party, nor OF any PARTY he has nc
yer done either me or my friends any good or i'll

acter of DIyanis OF Notaras.of Zarinis,ot Crondos
of Siseni, of Colletti, of Conduriottis, &c.--mcn


whose course has been uniformly one OF intrigue,
for their own private or party interest-negectine


their sacred duties to their country,to pursue selfish


nay, often criminal ends. BUTT is enough to say


to YOU that Greece is reduced to her present state


in great measure, by the jealousy. the lnrigues


and the secret opposition which one leader makes


80 another. have until now, abstained from max
ing this known in America, from motives OF consid
Grafton for the interest Of the country-hoping. al


ways. something .ht unite them but sec thu


hope is in vain-ana, perhaps, the sooner the worlt


knows the truth the better. 1t is not my own sin


gle private opinion which | express to you ever,


enlightened man in the country has long ielt ant


lamcnted if, and uow things have arrived to such =
pitch, that all feel it as | a common soder-asl
q simple wumao, what has brought the country t
its present state and the reply will invariably h'


1t OF megaloi r'--'.,he great'-and what is th'


cure ? 'sno fous mop..men!" " that their head


may fall" 1t is these men who have invariably


opposed the introduction Of order into the counr,


land why? Because, with it they must fall: il
the feet, in the army, in every department. OF ad
ministation. it is the same. The soldier looks no


to Government as his director, for he receives no
his pay from it he knows only his chief, and vii
blintIly follow him against another chief, Of even


aeainst the Government itself, with almost the same
aacrity as against the Turks The chiefs beins
thus superior TO the GoverI;nent practise the mos
abc.nnahle extortions, and have been growing rich

CONDITIONS.

THIS Institution viii be opened on Monday


the Goth Of October Inst, under the care


of the Rev. JOSEPH WnsoN.


In this Seminary students will be thoroughly in
sruced in the different branches of good English
and Classical Education, viz Reading, Writing,
Arithmetic, English Grammar, Geography, Compo-
llon. Elocution, Mathematics, and the Greek and
Latin Languages. The terms of tniton will be; for
the English branches, exclusive of Mathematics,
SO per session, or $40, including the Mathematics;
Tor the Languages, including the English, $40 per
session. Tuition money to be paid in advance.
There will be two sessions in the year, with q
Short vacation between each


Good boarding can be obtained in respectable
families in the village, at the rate of Forty Dollars
per session and few hoardegs can be acconamo
dated the family Of the Principal.


JOHN EDDOWES. Sec'y.

INTERESTING F3UM GREECE.

: NApoLI, July IA. 1877.
full articles.article:
Tr NApoII, July IA, 1891.


To I'm. l.. Stone, Esq. editor ofMe N I, &. .4do.


Sir: You lament the want of direct ana correct
information upon the condition and wants o Greece,
and you have reason to do so, nor you alone, but


poor Greece has reason bitterly to lament that her
situation is not known in America for had it been
Americans, by applying the means which they have
sent here in different manner, might have been
the means Of saving her from destruction. Greece,
my dear sir, is in deplorabe state-it is useless to
conceal truth her enemies without ignorant
and weak, but her enemies within are strong and
terrible; the Turk brings trouble and distress upon
the country. but the Greek brings teniod misery,
wOe and ruin. The accursed intrigues and Jealousy,
the avarice and lust of power of her civil and militia.


ry arstocracy have brought the country to the brink
of ruin. from which miracle only save her, and
that miracle would be the repentance and better
conduct of these men. Look, sir, at he state OF
the Peloponessus there YOU see the flag of liberty
waving upon the walls Of three proud fortresses !;
but these iorresses are the of intrigue. OF
plotting of secret. nay, Of open internal war. The
other night, while the army of the Pacha was with
in eight hours march of this place, was aroused
by the roar of cannon, and the rattlng of musket-
ry; arme myselfin the thought that the Turks
had made sudden assault upon the place. aud
was astonohed to find no movement on the part OF


the inhabitants-each remained still i'll his house,
. as though aware of what was going on ; and soon
= learned that Colocor0n, with a band OF soldiers,
had assaulted the castle, in hopes to master IT,
, and make himself independent, both by It's pos


session and that of the treasures Of DllyaDs, which


he knew were concealed here This is the man
= whom see YOU hold high in esteem in America, fol
his courage and patriotism =! Match me, ye Gods


match me another man who has drawn upon TN


Peloponessus so many mlserles Coocoruni.


They talk of Ibrahim Pacha he has ruined and


driven from their homes thousands Of ptaaantrv--
: Coocotron has ground them to the dust. and wrun!
e from them their little gain BY his enormous eSac
r tons the Pacha. has defeated the soltiery---Coo


coron has paralyzed them: the Pacha has opcnl
: assaulted and taken towns from his enem'es-Coo


cotroni has worked to gain hy intrigue; and assault


ed at midnight castles and towns held By men ACTIN
under the orders of government the Pacha has dis
- trcssed the government by hts movements aud depre
dations--Coortroni has still more distressed it b.
N his demands for pay and rations for armies whlc
he never raised by his intrigue by his secret opposi
- ton and open war. Leave aside his proceedings II
n 1924, his nrigues and open opposition aud rebellion
against the lawful governmenths defeat and lmpr's
s. onmen lsAas look at him since his leaving his con
,c hnement Svhe monastery at Hydra, and his berom
a. ling ceneral-in chief of TIL Morea how often an


loudly has he talked Of the death and destru ction
was preparing for the Turks how often has denan


ded and received large supplies from government


and from his province, which he has either sold OF
H. given to his creatures it is true, he has sailed on

against the enemy-he has examined them with his
spy-glass from some mountain side but never, no,
not in one single instance, has he or his Immediate
followers ventured their precious persons within the
range of shot He is bold and daring. but not before
an armed enemy; it is in int rigue and plotting to
get himself and friends in power it is in pundering
and anassing treasures for his own Golfers Where
are the of TlppoIizza, and Napo'l, which
he took as Commander inchietfr the Government!
Where his bankers in Zane, and different parts OF
Italy, where he has large sums. while he makes the
poor peasantry pay for the articles Of his own
table. How he got his former reputation for courage
know not but now his name here is getting to be
a mockery. and he is known only as a man who will
sacrifice the public for party good. who would sell
his country, nay, his soul, his God, for gold. My
language may seem to you strong and impasslonet,
but ii is the language OF man, who engaged with
all hsheart in the best cause Tor which people ever
vet drew the sword, sees that cause endangered by
the sefshness of those most bound TO support 1t !;
of one, who sees his adopted country about to be
sacrificed on the altar olavarlce and selfish ambition;
of one. who ignorant but naturally anteUagea
and virtuous people neglected nay betrayed by their
leaders. speak to YOU Of Coloctroni-not because
he alone ia the Of iniquity, not because he
ia the worst--hut, because his name sknown TO you


am not of his party, nor OF any PARTY he has nc
yer done either me or my friends any good or i'll
] speak of him as public character, and could
sneak to you of Others--i could tell you OF the char
acter of DIyanis OF Notaras.of Zarinis,ot Crondos
of Siseni, of Colletti, of Conduriottis, &c.--mcn


whose course has been uniformly one OF intrigue,
for their own private or party interest-negectine


their sacred duties to their country,to pursue selfish


nay, often criminal ends. BUTT is enough to say


to YOU that Greece is reduced to her present state


in great measure, by the jealousy. the lnrigues


and the secret opposition which one leader makes


80 another. have until now, abstained from max
ing this known in America, from motives OF consid
Grafton for the interest Of the country-hoping. al


ways. something .ht unite them but sec thu


hope is in vain-ana, perhaps, the sooner the worlt


knows the truth the better. 1t is not my own sin


gle private opinion which | express to you ever,


enlightened man in the country has long ielt ant


lamcnted if, and uow things have arrived to such =
pitch, that all feel it as | a common soder-asl
q simple wumao, what has brought the country t
its present state and the reply will invariably h'


1t OF megaloi r'--'.,he great'-and what is th'


cure ? 'sno fous mop..men!" " that their head


may fall" 1t is these men who have invariably


opposed the introduction Of order into the counr,


land why? Because, with it they must fall: il
the feet, in the army, in every department. OF ad
ministation. it is the same. The soldier looks no


to Government as his director, for he receives no
his pay from it he knows only his chief, and vii
blintIly follow him against another chief, Of even


aeainst the Government itself, with almost the same
aacrity as against the Turks The chiefs beins
thus superior TO the GoverI;nent practise the mos
abc.nnahle extortions, and have been growing rich
